newsitem.title: ESTONIA: MOST STOCKS LOWER AS BOURSE BEGINS SLIDE.
newsitem.headline: MOST STOCKS LOWER AS BOURSE BEGINS SLIDE.

text.p: * Total trade at 99.1 million kroons vs 74.9 million kroons.
* Index 1.27 percent lower to 345.54.
* 26 stocks traded: 18 down, 4 up, 4 steady.
* Hansapank turns over 38.6 million kroons to lose
1.75 kroons to 190.75 kroons.
* Farmaatsiatehas 0.25 kroons higher at 135 kroons
after 18.2 million kroons traded.
* Uhispank was 4.05 kroons down at 66.20 kroons
on 14.8 million kroons traded.
* Hansapank released its revised profit forecastof 475
million kroon profit for the Hansa group in 1997, up from an
earlier estimate of 320 million kroons.
(A complete report follows)
(See the stock exchange web site: http://www.tse.ee/stat/)
Most shares eased again on
Tuesday, with dealers expecting further slides in prices in
the coming days.
Total trade on the main list was 92.3 million kroons with
the Talse 1.27 percent lower to close at 345.54.
"There were more sellers about today and most banking stocks
could keep moving lower tomorrow," one trader said.
Hansapank was the most active stock with 38.6 million kroons
traded to be 1.75 lower at 190.75 kroons despite revising
upwards its profit forecast for 1997.
"The selling pressure started in the morning in Hansapank,
and except for a small jump after the release of the revised
profit figures the selling pressure stayed," one dealer said.
"We are seeing some profit-taking in Hansapank now and
because August is expected to be slow, the price will just ease
down," another said.
Hansapank revised its profit estimates for 1997 and
predicted a new group profit 475 million kroons up from 320
million kroons.
Farmaatsiatehase moved slighly higher with some bigger
blocks taking it against the downward trend.
Farma closed at 135 kroons, up 0.25 kroons after turning
over 18.2 million kroons.
On the free market, 6.7 million kroons changed hands with
Norma, an automotive safety belt manufacturer, the most active.
Norma lost 1.50 kroons to close at 88.50 kroons after trade
of 2.8 million kroons despite increasing its 1997 forecast.
-- David Mardiste, Tallinn newsroom, +372 620 9202,
reuters@reuters.ee
